Annotation: The seminal result showing the possibility of secure computation among three or more parties, given that a majority of players is honest. Describes a ``protocol compiler'' for transforming protocols secure against semi-honest adversaries into protocols secure against malicious adversaries. Computational security.

The seminal result showing the possibility of secure computation among three or more parties, given that a majority of players is honest. Describes a ``protocol compiler'' for transforming protocols secure against semi-honest adversaries into protocols secure against malicious adversaries. Computational security.

The first result showing the possibility of information-theoretically secure multi-party computation. Proves that information-theoretically secure MPC requires strictly less than $n/2$ corrupted players if the adversary is semi-honest, or less than $n/3$ in the case of a malicious adversary.

The first result showing the possibility of information-theoretically secure multi-party computation. Proves that information-theoretically secure MPC requires strictly less than $n/2$ corrupted players if the adversary is semi-honest, or less than $n/3$ in the case of a malicious adversary.

Gives an MPC protocol that is unconditionally secure in the presence of an honest majority, with exponentially small error, by assuming a broadcast channel. [BGW88] proved that with no error, the number of corrupted parties must be $< n/3$.

Result showing that cryptographically-secure, multiparty computation is achievable in a constant number of rounds, if a broadcast channel is assumed. Important follow-up work on round complexity for MPC includes [KOS03], [DI05].

The foundational work in \emph{asynchronous} MPC, in which no messages are guaranteed to arrive in bounded time, thus preventing the round enforcement of standard MPC protocols. Shows that asynchronous MPC is possible for up to $n/3$ maliciously corrupted players.

The foundational work in \emph{asynchronous} MPC, in which no messages are guaranteed to arrive in bounded time, thus preventing the round enforcement of standard MPC protocols. Shows that asynchronous MPC is possible for up to $n/3$ maliciously corrupted players.

First result showing security against an \emph{adaptive} adversary, which is able to dynamically choose which parties to corrupt in the course of the computation, based on its view.  A protocol is given which is secure against an adaptive adversary corrupting a minority of parties, without requiring that parties be trusted to delete their computation records.

Shows that the protocol of [RB89] is not secure against adaptive adversaries, and gives a more efficient protocol that is unconditionally secure (with non-zero error probability) against up to $n/2$ adaptive adversaries, in the broadcast channel model. Can also be modified to support adversary structures.

Gives an unconditionally secure multi-party computation protocol which is also \emph{$t$-robust}, meaning that an adversary corrupting up to $t < n/3$ parties cannot corrupt the \emph{output} of the computation.

Overcomes known limits on the use of Byzantine agreement to emulate broadcast channels in MPC, by introducing a weaker version of fairness in which not all honest parties may receive the same output. The protocol achieves MPC with this security level with composability for a dishonest majority.

Overcomes known limits on the use of Byzantine agreement to emulate broadcast channels in MPC, by introducing a weaker version of fairness in which not all honest parties may receive the same output. The protocol achieves MPC with this security level with composability for a dishonest majority.
Gives the first MPC protocols secure against a mobile adversary, who can corrupt different subsets of adversaries at each round.
Efficiency improvement on [SR00a] for asynchronous MPC.

Uses universal composability results of [Can00] to give the first two-party and multi-party protocols secure against up to n-1 adaptively and actively corrupted parties. Requires trusted setup of a "common reference string".

A protocol for universally composable secure MPC that preserves security under concurrent executions. This is the first protocol to achieve this for a dishonest majority without requiring setup assumptions such as a common reference string.
Shows constant-round multiparty computation, with a malicious adversary corrupting a minority of parties, founded only on the use of a PRG.

Gives an unconditionally secure MPC protocol against up to $n/2$ corrupted parties in the broadcast model, with improved broadcast efficiency over [CDD+99]; only $n^2$ bits of communication per multiplication.

Gives the first MPC protocol secure against a malicious, adaptive ([CFGN96]) adversary with no honest majority, with a constant number of rounds, without requiring trusted setup as in [CLOS02]. The new technique is a non-blackbox simulator.
A protocol providing unconditional security against a malicious adversary adaptively corrupting $t < n/2$ players, which matches the communication complexity of the semi-honest case.

A protocol in the preprocessing model which is statistically UC-secure against a malicious adversary corrupting up to $n-1$ players, with linear computation and communication complexity in the online phase. The offline phase makes use of somewhat homomorphic encryption.

A more efficient protocol for perfectly-secure asynchronous MPC with malicious, adaptive  adversaries. It achieves the optimal bound of up to n/4 corrupted players, and requires O(n^3) communication per multiplication.

Gives universally composable protocols in the preprocessing model for constant-round multi-party computation, secure against an adversary corrupting an arbitrary number of parties. Provides fairness if there are less than n/2 corrupted parties.
The first major efficiency improvement (over [CLOS02]) for MPC against a dishonest majority, using a preprocessing phase with a cut-and-choose technique. Followed by [BDOZ11] and [DPSZ12].

Uses Gentry's semi-homomorphic encryption to construct a UC MPC protocol secure against dishonest majority. Has a function-independent preprocessing phase and a highly efficient online phase. Result is improved by [DPSZ12].
Describes an implementation of the protocol of [DPSZ12], with modifications to improve efficiency by a covert rather than malicious adversary model. Efficiency results are presented for AES.
Efficiency improvements on [DPSZ12].

Gives the first amortized linear-communication asynchronous MPC protocols, for up to n/4  corrupted parties in the pure asynchronous model  with statistical security, and with perfect security in a hybrid setting with one synchronous round.

Gives the first amortized linear-communication asynchronous MPC protocols, for up to n/4  corrupted parties in the pure asynchronous model  with statistical security, and with perfect security in a hybrid setting with one synchronous round.
